subject: mathematics

explanations.stepByStep: When comparing fractions with the same numerator (1), the fraction with the smallest denominator is the largest. Since 2 < 3 < 4 < 5 < 6, we have 1/2 is the largest fraction.
explanations.visual: Imagine cutting a pizza: 1/2 means 2 pieces (big slices), 1/6 means 6 pieces (small slices). Fewer pieces means each piece is bigger!
explanations.workedExample: Compare 1/3 and 1/4: Since 3 < 4, we have 1/3 > 1/4. Think: 'thirds are bigger than quarters'.

curriculumReference: KS2 Maths - Fractions - Compare and order fractions

subject: mathematics

explanations.visual: All fractions are close to 1. Find which is furthest from 1: 3/4 needs 1/4 more, 2/3 needs 1/3 more. Since 1/3 > 1/4, then 2/3 is smallest.
explanations.workedExample: Compare 2/3 and 3/4 using cross-multiplication: 2×4 = 8, 3×3 = 9. Since 8 < 9, we have 2/3 < 3/4.

curriculumReference: KS2 Maths - Fractions - Compare and order fractions

subject: mathematics
questionText: Put these fractions in order from smallest to largest: 1/2, 1/4, 3/4, 1/8

explanations.visual: Think of a chocolate bar with 8 squares: 1/8 = 1 square, 1/4 = 2 squares, 1/2 = 4 squares, 3/4 = 6 squares.
explanations.workedExample: Compare 1/4 and 3/4: same denominator, so compare numerators. 1 < 3, therefore 1/4 < 3/4.

explanations.stepByStep: To find equivalent fractions, multiply numerator and denominator by the same number: 2/3 = (2×2)/(3×2) = 4/6.
explanations.visual: If you have 2 out of 3 equal parts, this is the same as having 4 out of 6 equal parts (each original part split in two).

subject: mathematics
questionText: Which of these fractions is greater than 1/2?

explanations.visual: Half of 8 is 4, so 5/8 means 5 parts when we need 4 for half. That's more than half!
explanations.workedExample: For 5/8: is 5 more than half of 8? Half of 8 is 4, and 5 > 4, so yes, 5/8 > 1/2.

subject: mathematics

explanations.stepByStep: Find distance from 1: 7/8 needs 1/8 (0.125), 5/6 needs 1/6 (0.167), 9/10 needs 1/10 (0.1), 11/12 needs 1/12 (0.083), 3/4 needs 1/4 (0.25). Smallest distance is 1/12.
explanations.visual: Think how many parts are missing: 11/12 is missing just 1 part out of 12 (smallest gap), 3/4 is missing 1 part out of 4 (biggest gap).
explanations.workedExample: Compare 11/12 and 9/10: 11/12 ≈ 0.917 and 9/10 = 0.9. Both close to 1, but 0.917 is closer.

curriculumReference: KS2 Maths - Fractions - Compare and order fractions

subject: mathematics
questionText: Put these fractions in order from largest to smallest: 2/3, 3/5, 5/6, 1/2

explanations.visual: Think of a 30-slice pizza (common denominator): 5/6 = 25 slices, 2/3 = 20 slices, 3/5 = 18 slices, 1/2 = 15 slices.
explanations.workedExample: Compare 2/3 and 3/5: cross-multiply: 2×5 = 10, 3×3 = 9. Since 10 > 9, we have 2/3 > 3/5.

explanations.stepByStep: 3/4 = (3×2)/(4×2) = 6/8. Multiply both numerator and denominator by 2 to get equivalent fraction.
explanations.visual: 3/4 means 3 parts out of 4. If you split each part in half, you get 6 parts out of 8 total parts - same amount!
explanations.workedExample: Check: 3÷4 = 0.75 and 6÷8 = 0.75. Same decimal value means equivalent fractions.

explanations.visual: Imagine a number line from 0 to 1. Mark 1/4 (quarter way) and 1/2 (halfway). 1/3 (one-third) falls between these marks.
explanations.workedExample: Compare: 1/4 < 1/3 because 4 > 3 (smaller denominator = bigger fraction). Also 1/3 < 1/2 because 3 > 2.

subject: mathematics
questionText: Which fraction is NOT equivalent to 1/2?

explanations.visual: For 1/2, the numerator must be exactly half the denominator: 2 is half of 4, 3 is half of 6, etc. But 5 is not half of 9.
explanations.workedExample: Check 5/9: half of 9 is 4.5, not 5. So 5/9 ≠ 1/2.

subject: mathematics
questionText: Which is the correct order from smallest to largest: 1/6, 1/3, 1/2?

explanations.stepByStep: With same numerator (1), compare denominators: 6 > 3 > 2, so 1/6 < 1/3 < 1/2. Larger denominator means smaller fraction.
explanations.visual: Cut a cake into 6 pieces vs 2 pieces. A sixth is smaller than a half because you're dividing into more pieces.

explanations.stepByStep: 3/5 = (3×2)/(5×2) = 6/10. Multiply both numerator and denominator by the same number.
explanations.visual: 3 out of 5 parts equals 6 out of 10 parts - imagine splitting each of the 5 parts into 2 smaller parts.
2/5 = 0.4 and 3/7 ≈ 0.429. 3/7 is slightly larger.

subject: mathematics
questionText: Put these fractions in order from smallest to largest: 5/8, 3/8, 7/8, 1/8

explanations.stepByStep: Same denominator (8), so just compare numerators: 1 < 3 < 5 < 7. Order: 1/8, 3/8, 5/8, 7/8.
explanations.visual: Think of 8 equal chocolate squares. 1 square < 3 squares < 5 squares < 7 squares.
explanations.workedExample: When fractions have the same denominator, the one with the smaller numerator is smaller: 1/8 < 3/8.

explanations.visual: 2/3 means 6 out of 9 parts. 5/9 is only 5 parts, which is less than 6 parts.
explanations.workedExample: Convert to ninths: 2/3 = 6/9. Compare with 5/9: 5 < 6, so 5/9 < 2/3.

explanations.stepByStep: Simplify 4/6 by dividing both by 2: 4÷2 = 2 and 6÷2 = 3, giving 2/3.
explanations.visual: 4 out of 6 parts is the same as 2 out of 3 parts - divide each group of 2 parts into 1.
Each fraction is 1 part away from being whole: 2/3 needs 1/3, 3/4 needs 1/4, 4/5 needs 1/5, 5/6 needs 1/6. Smallest gap (1/6) means closest to 1.
explanations.workedExample: Compare 4/5 and 5/6: cross-multiply: 4×6 = 24, 5×5 = 25. Since 25 > 24, we have 5/6 > 4/5.

subject: mathematics
questionText: Put these fractions in order from largest to smallest: 1/3, 2/5, 1/2, 3/10

explanations.visual: 1/3 is one-third of the way, 2/3 is two-thirds. 1/2 (halfway) is right in the middle!

subject: mathematics
questionText: Which fraction is NOT equivalent to 3/4?

explanations.visual: For equivalence to 3/4, numerator must be 3/4 of denominator: 3/4 of 16 is 12, not 9.
explanations.workedExample: Check 9/16: simplify by dividing by 9: can't reduce to 3/4. Calculate: 9÷16 = 0.5625 ≠ 0.75.

explanations.visual: Half of 11 is 5.5, and 5 is very close to 5.5. This makes 5/11 nearly half.
explanations.workedExample: Compare 5/11 to 1/2: 5/11 vs 5.5/11. Only 0.5 difference in numerator!

explanations.visual: 3/5 = 0.6 and 4/7 ≈ 0.571. 3/5 is slightly larger.
explanations.workedExample: Convert to 35ths: 3/5 = 21/35 and 4/7 = 20/35. Since 21 > 20, we have 3/5 > 4/7.

subject: mathematics
questionText: Put these fractions in order from smallest to largest: 7/12, 2/3, 3/4, 5/6

explanations.visual: Think of a clock (12 hours): 7/12, 8/12, 9/12, 10/12 - increasing by 1 twelfth each time.

explanations.stepByStep: Simplify 5/10: divide both by 5 to get 1/2. Also, 2/4 simplified equals 1/2. So both C and D are equivalent!
explanations.visual: 5 out of 10 parts = half. 1 out of 2 parts = half. 2 out of 4 parts = half. All the same!
3/4 is three-quarters. 4/5 is four-fifths, which is closer to a whole (only 1/5 away vs 1/4 away).
explanations.workedExample: Compare distances from 1: 3/4 needs 1/4 (0.25), 4/5 needs 1/5 (0.2). Since 0.2 < 0.25, 4/5 is larger.

explanations.visual: Think of 8 equal parts: 3 parts < 4 parts < 5 parts < 6 parts.

subject: mathematics
questionText: Which two fractions from this list are equivalent: 2/5, 4/10, 3/6, 5/8?

explanations.visual: 2 out of 5 parts equals 4 out of 10 parts - each part split in two.

subject: mathematics
questionText: Put these fractions in order from largest to smallest: 4/5, 7/10, 3/4, 9/10

explanations.visual: As decimals: 9/10 = 0.9, 4/5 = 0.8, 3/4 = 0.75, 7/10 = 0.7. Descending order.
On a number line from 0 to 1: 1/2 is at 0.5, 3/4 at 0.75. 2/3 at 0.667 falls between them.

explanations.stepByStep: Simplify 6/9: divide both by 3 to get 2/3. Also, 4/6 simplified (divide by 2) equals 2/3. Both are equivalent!
explanations.visual: 6 out of 9 parts = 2 out of 3 parts (group in threes). 4 out of 6 parts = 2 out of 3 parts (group in twos).

explanations.stepByStep: Convert to 24ths: 5/12 = 10/24 and 3/8 = 9/24. Since 9 < 10, we have 3/8 < 5/12.

subject: mathematics
questionText: Order these fractions from smallest to largest: 2/7, 3/7, 1/7, 5/7

explanations.stepByStep: Same denominator (7), so just order numerators: 1 < 2 < 3 < 5. Order: 1/7, 2/7, 3/7, 5/7.
explanations.visual: Think of 7 equal chocolate pieces. 1 piece < 2 pieces < 3 pieces < 5 pieces.
explanations.workedExample: When denominators are the same, smaller numerator means smaller fraction: 1/7 is the smallest.

subject: mathematics
questionText: Which fraction is less than 1/2 but greater than 1/3?

subject: mathematics
questionText: Which fraction is NOT equivalent to 2/5?

explanations.visual: For 2/5, numerator is 2/5 of denominator: 2/5 of 15 is 6, not 8.
explanations.workedExample: Check 8/15: simplify by dividing by common factors. 8 and 15 have no common factors except 1, so can't reduce to 2/5.

explanations.visual: All are close to 1/2 (0.5). 3/5 = 0.6 is furthest above 0.5.

subject: mathematics
questionText: Put these fractions in order from largest to smallest: 1/4, 2/8, 3/12, 1/2

explanations.stepByStep: Simplify: 1/4 = 1/4, 2/8 = 1/4, 3/12 = 1/4. So 1/4, 2/8, and 3/12 are all equal! Only 1/2 is larger.
explanations.visual: 1/4, 2/8, and 3/12 are all equivalent to one-quarter. 1/2 (half) is twice as big.
Quarter of 11 is 2.75, and 3 is very close to 2.75.
explanations.workedExample: Compare 3/11 to 1/4: 3/11 ≈ 0.273 vs 0.25. Difference is only 0.023!

explanations.stepByStep: Simplify 8/12: divide both by 4 to get 2/3.
explanations.visual: 8 out of 12 parts = 2 out of 3 parts (group in fours).
7/8 = 0.875 and 5/6 ≈ 0.833. 7/8 is slightly larger.

subject: mathematics
questionText: Order these fractions from smallest to largest: 3/10, 2/5, 1/2, 7/10

explanations.visual: Think of a 10-square chocolate bar: 3 squares < 4 squares < 5 squares < 7 squares.

explanations.stepByStep: Simplify: 3/9 = 1/3 (divide by 3), 4/12 = 1/3 (divide by 4). All three equal 1/3!
explanations.visual: 3 out of 9 = 1 out of 3 (group in threes). 4 out of 12 = 1 out of 3 (group in fours).

subject: mathematics
questionText: Put these fractions in order from largest to smallest: 5/12, 1/3, 1/4, 1/2

explanations.stepByStep: Convert to twelfths: 5/12 = 5/12, 1/3 = 4/12, 1/4 = 3/12, 1/2 = 6/12. Order from largest: 6, 5, 4, 3.

subject: mathematics
questionText: Which fraction is greater than 3/5 but less than 4/5?

explanations.stepByStep: Simplify 9/12: divide both by 3 to get 3/4.
explanations.visual: 9 out of 12 parts = 3 out of 4 parts (group in threes).
Cross-multiply: 4×11 = 44 and 5×9 = 45. Since 44 < 45, we have 4/9 < 5/11.
explanations.workedExample: Compare to 1/2: 4/9 = 8/18 < 9/18 and 5/11 = 10/22 > 11/22. Both close but 4/9 is further below half.

subject: mathematics
questionText: Order these fractions from smallest to largest: 4/6, 2/3, 8/12, 10/15

explanations.stepByStep: Simplify all: 4/6 = 2/3, 2/3 = 2/3, 8/12 = 2/3, 10/15 = 2/3. All four fractions are equivalent!
explanations.visual: All simplify to 2 out of 3 parts. They're the same amount!
3/4 = 0.75. 7/9 ≈ 0.778 is very close, difference is only 0.028!
explanations.workedExample: Convert to 36ths: 3/4 = 27/36 and 7/9 = 28/36. Only 1 thirty-sixth apart!

subject: mathematics
questionText: Which fraction is NOT equivalent to 5/6?

explanations.visual: For 5/6, numerator should be 5/6 of denominator: 5/6 of 36 is 30, not 25.
explanations.workedExample: Simplify 25/36: no common factors except 1. Can't reduce to 5/6. Check: 25÷36 ≈ 0.694 ≠ 0.833.
